folder: Hudson Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Hudson Street, east side, between Ericsson Place (Beach Street) and Laight Street, showing the frieze and entablature atop the St. Johns Park Freight Terminal of the New York Central Railroad Company. This structure, erected 1868 by the Hudson River Railroad (chartered 1846 and consolidated into the New York Central and Hudson Railroad in 1869), occupies the land that was formerly St. Johns Park. Facing St. Johns Chapel on Varick Street, it provided a picturesque setting. The spire of the Chapel appears at the top.

About 1890

Ewing Galloway

folder: Beach Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
38 Beach Street, south side, east of Hudson Street.

June 13, 1913.

Frank Cousins Art Co.
Salem, Mass.

Gift of the Art Commission.
December 7, 1915.

folder: Hudson Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY
text: (1) 143-145 Hudson Street, west side, between Beach (to-day (1937) Ericsson Place) and Hubert Streets. About 1915. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.  (2) The same. About 1915. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Hudson Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY
text: (1) 143-145 Hudson Street, west side, between Beach (to-day (1937) Ericsson Place) and Hubert Streets. About 1915. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.  (2) The same. About 1915. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Hudson Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)

Hudson Street, north from Beach Street (Ericsson Place), showing the St. John's Freight Depot of the New York Central Railroad extending north-ward on the east side , to Light Street. This building was razed in 1936. Beach Street, east of Hudson to Varick Street, becomes Ericsson Place.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, showing the west side of Hudson Street.

October 10, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

The same as No. 2, at a later date.

March 6, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Hudson Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Hudson Street, north from Ericsson Place (Beach Street). Across clearance on the east side, appears Laight Street, north side, east from Hudson to, but not including Varick Street.

November 27, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
